This is the suggested reading of the editor. It makes perfect sense because the Hebrew and Greek texts compliment one another. Note that the Hebrew ש represents here the Greek suffix ος, see Introduction 2.2.5.

See Introduction 6.3.2. In BT R. Tarfon is said to have forbidden Israelites to mourn him (bHag18a). This may suggest that the Babylonians understood he was not Jewish and the issue was mourning over gentiles. In the early Tosefta the problem in the same tradition is mourning on a festival. אלכסא is certainly not identified as a gentile.

See Introduction 6.3.1. Since this person is found in the same cave with Nicanor, the Alexandrian Jew mentioned in rabbinic literature, one may assume that he too was of Alexandria. Another way of interpreting the evidence is to assume that this is itself a nickname, denoting Nicanor’s place of origin. On father names as nicknames, see Introduction 6.1.1.

This is the version recorded in Josephus. It is obviously a Greek name and ̓́Αμφικλος is the most likely. On the double λ, see Introduction 2.3.4. On the ει suffix see Introduction 2.1.2.2.

This is the version in rabbinic literature. ב is occasionally used to transliterate φ, see Introduction 2.2.2. Jastrow, DTTBYML, 8, suggests the name transliterated here is Εὔκολος (WGE, 411) but he does not take into account the Josephan parallel.

Derenbourg, Essai, 267, suggested that Ζαχαρίας δέ τις υἱὸς ̓Αμφικάλλει in Josephus should be identified with זכריה בן אבקולס of rabbinicliterature. Rabbinic literature assigns actions to the latter that Josephus ascribes to ̓Ελεάζαρος υἱὸς ̓Ανανία (Eleazar no. 8), but this literature is famous for making historical mistakes. Nevertheless, at the background of rabbinic stories one finds reliable traditions (that were, apparently, also available to Josephus), which were then distorted by the rabbis, because of their disinterest in history (Cohen, “Parallel Traditions,” 7-14; Ilan & Price, JQR 84 1993] 206, n. 66).
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This is probably the same name as אבקלוס. Here, however, פ transliterates φ as would be expected.

This declension is recorded in the document. The Greek feminine name̓Ανδρώ, also exists, and this would be its correct genetive (WGE, 89). G. Mayer, Die jüdische Frau in der hellenistisch-römischen Antike(Stuttgart 1987) 111 (after him, Ilan, Jewish Women, 47, n. 8) interpreted this name as feminine. However I suspect that the Jews of Palestine were not very well versed in Greek case suffixes and that probably a genetive of a male name was intended, see Andreas no. 3. The name is also recorded as male in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 30).
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

See above, n. 3. This declension is recorded in the document. The Greek feminine name̓Ανδρώ, also exists, and this would be its correct genetive (WGE, 89). G. Mayer, Die jüdische Frau in der hellenistisch-römischen Antike(Stuttgart 1987) 111 (after him, Ilan, Jewish Women, 47, n. 8) interpreted this name as feminine. However I suspect that the Jews of Palestine were not very well versed in Greek case suffixes and that probably a genetive of a male name was intended, see Andreas no. 3. The name is also recorded as male in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 30). That this is a male is indicated by the fact that the name is portrayed as a parent name, which makes most sense as a father’s name. Mothers’ names are also recorded (Ilan, Nov Test 34 [1992]) but they are rare and should methodologically only be identified as such when there is no other alternative.

The use of the name ̓Αντίοχος among Jews, after the anti-Jewish decrees issued by a king of this name in 168 BCE, seems strange. This person, however, was born before these events and cannot, therefore, count as an unusual phenomenon.
On the dependence of Josephus on 1 Macc see Introduction 5.1.1.
On dating in 1 Macc, see Introduction 7.1.2.

The use of the name ̓Αντίοχοςby this person (see above, n. 2) is perhaps harder to explain. We can assume that the events associated with this name had meanwhile become somewhat remote. Alternatively, a Diaspora Jew living in a city named after kings of this name (Antioch) in Syria, where kings by this name had ruled and were still popular, can explain the phenomenon (Fuks, IEJ 31 (1981) 237-8).

person.note: So I understand the name of this person, despite the evidence of Julius Africanus, recorded in Eusebius, that Antipatrus’s father was named ̔Ηρώδης (Eus. EH1:7:11). On the possibility that this Herod of Ashkelon was Antipatrus no. 8’ father, see Kokkinos, Herodian Dynasty 108-9. In any case, even if this were true, this remote ancestor – Herod – was not Jewish, but Idumean. On Herodians see Introduction 1.2.4.4.

It has been suggested by scholars that the coin of “Bacchius Iudaeus” of 54 BCE, should be identified with the Διονύσιος, the ruler of Tripoli, mentioned in Josephus’ description of the Roman conquest of the East (AJ14:39). This makes sense because Bacchus is the Latin incarnation of the Greek god Dionysus.

Only if he is identified with Bacchus Judaios of the coins (see above, n. 2) could he be considered Jewish (or perhaps only a native of Judaea?). Josephus fails to mention that this person was Jewish.

This is my suggested reading, based on other persons by the name found in the same burial chamber. It was suggested to me that the genetive suffix ας suggests the female name ̓Ερώτα (Ilan, IAAR 1 [1996]), but this is an artificial construction of a non-documented name (̓Ερωτᾶς is documented –LGPN I, 167 – but it is probably the male genetive), and ̓́Ερως is frequently documented. The forms ̓Ερώτας and ̓́Ερωτος (as well as ̓Ηροῦτος, see under ̔Ηρᾶς) are found in this same cave.

This is clearly not a Semitic name, since it includes several features usually associated with names of Greek origin. The אפ stands for Ευ, typical in Greek (see Introduction 2.2.1). For the יון suffix see Introduction 2.4.3.3. I assume that the cluster קש stands for ξ(see Introduction 2.2.5). However, note that the form Ε̓κᾶς is recorded on an Egyptian papyrus (Foraboschi, NB, 114).

Quoted by Alexander Polyhistor (mid 1st C BCE) and last date he mentions in his extant writings is 158-7 BCE (Holladay, Fragments, 99, n. 4).

On אב as ευ see Introduction 2.2.1. Derenbourg, Essai, 149, n. 1, suggests that אבטליון is the biblical אביטל with an Aramaic suffix, see Introduction 2.4.3.3. The name אבטל is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 9). Feldman, JQR 49 (1958-9) 53-7, identifies the name as Greek (sic) and as Πολλίων. He identifies rabbinic אבטליון with Πολλίων of Josephus, see under Pollio (L/M).
One rabbinic tradition has it that שמעיה and אבטליון were proselytes (bSan 96b) see Introduction 6.3.3 but this is rather unlikely.
One of the “pairs,” see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

On אב as ευ see Introduction 2.2.1. I assumed this is the closest recorded Greek name. Jastrow, DTTBYML, 4, suggests Πτολεμαῖος (see under Ptolemy) or Ε̓πτόλεμος or Ε̓πόλεμος (see under Eupolemus).
In this tradition R. Yosi cites him as a senior, see Introduction 7.5.1.2-3.

See above, n. 2. On אב as ευ see Introduction 2.2.1. I assumed this is the closest recorded Greek name. Jastrow, DTTBYML, 4, suggests Πτολεμαῖος (see under Ptolemy) or Ε̓πτόλεμος or Ε̓πόλεμος (see under Eupolemus). אבטולמוס is an oft recorded name in rabbinic literature. This is the only אבטלוס. I assume it is a scribal variation, see Introduction 2.7.1. Zunz, Namen, 13, suggest that it is Α̓τόλαυς. WGE, 178, however, records this only as a ciy name. LGPN 1, 95, records the name ̓Αυτολῆς.
In Hebrew – הזקן. On this title see Introduction 3.2.3.

person.note: The form אבטלוס is recorded in bShab. 118b, see above, n. 4. See above, n. 2. אבטולמוס is an oft recorded name in rabbinic literature. This is the only אבטלוס. I assume it is a scribal variation, see Introduction 2.7.1. Zunz, Namen, 13, suggest that it is Α̓τόλαυς. WGE, 178, however, records this only as a ciy name. LGPN 1, 95, records the name ̓Αυτολῆς.
Zunz, Namen, 14, suggests that this is the Greek Ε̓ρύδεμος. For this Greek name see WGE, 420; Jastrow, DTTBYML, 375.

The question whether this is a Greek or an Aramaic name has been debated. On the Greek side we find 1. Jastrow, DTTBYML, 3 – Εὔδημος(WGE, 404); 2. Zunz, Namen, 15 – ̔Ηβδομος (=the seventh, which is like the Latin Septimius). WGE records no such Greek name. On the other hand, Klein Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 328, following the talmudic explanation (Gen Rab 85:8), suggested that it is a nickname and means “the son looks like the father” (although the midrash states that it means he looks like the mother).
Son of R. Yosi, see Introduction 7.5.2.

This is the transliteration of this Greek form into Hebrew. In the list of Jesus’ disciples mentioned in the censored bSan 43a this is one that has a clear parallel in the Gospels. However, the transliteration was made to fit the verse interpreted through it (איתיוה לתודה. אמר: תודה יהרג? הכתיב "מזמור לתודה" [תהלים ק א]. א"ל: אין, תודה יהרג, דכתיב "זובח תודה יכבדנני" [תהלים נ כב]) rather than comply with strict rules of correct transliteration. This inscription is bilingual. It displays the form Θεόδωρος and the Hebrew parallel תודוס. This case convinced me that all Hebrew תודוס, should be considered equivalent to the Greek Θεόδωρος, although Θεόδοτος and Θεοδόσιος are just as likely candidates.

This inscription further consists of the form Θεόδωρος as parallel to the abbreviated Θευδᾶς. This example convinced me that all cases of Θευδᾶς should be considered equivalent to the Greek Θεόδωρος. This form is also recorded as a Greek name (WGE, 502), but mostly for Jews, and see Introduction 2.4.2.10. For Θευ as Θεο see Introduction 2.3.1.

However, Jastrow, DTTBYML, 930, suggested that the disciple intended here is Lucas.

Θολομαί is a transcription of the biblical תלמי (e.g. 2 Sam 13:37 – Schlatter, HN, 114; H & R Suppl. 72). Rabbinic literature, however, by designating Ptolemaic kings תלמי, indicate that the distinction between the biblical תלמי and the Greek Πτολεμαῖος is unwarranted.

According to this tradition, this person was as executed by the sages in Lydda. According to tShab 11:15 he engaged in tattooing, an action condemned by the rabbis. PT elaborates on this tradition. In yShab 12:4, 13d he is described as tattooing himself with spells and thus bringing them from Egypt. All this data together was interpreted by BT (bShab 104b) as referring to Jesus. The name was understood as that of Jesus’ mother or father. A name midrash interpreted it as a slur on his mother’s fidelity: "א"ר חסדא: בעל סטדא, בועל פנדירא. פפוס בן יהודה הוא. אלא אמו סטדא. אמו מגדלא נשיא הואי, אלא כדאמרי בפומבדיתא: סטית דא מבעלה" (bShab104b Mun. Ms.).

The scribe who wrote this document was obviously not well versed in Greek orthography (see also how he spelt Ε̓δόμος). This seems to be the name he wished to spell. Note that the feminine ̓́Ωκιμον was used as a hetaera (namely a slave) name. This person is also a slave and may have received a typical slave name for the occasion of his being sold, in the document where he is mentioned.

div.note: Greek, WGE, 23. This name derives from the Greek goddess Athena. On such Greek names see Introduction 1.2.1.

Greek, WGE, 37. Aenaeas was an important mythical figure for both Greeks and Romans, since he was the hero of Troy (e.g. Homer, Iliad 2:820), who then founded Rome. On mythical names, see Introduction 1.2.1.

Greek, WGE, 55. Alexander is another name Homer uses for the Tojan prince Paris (Ilias3:16). On such names in this corpus see Introduction 1.2.1. This is the most popular Greek name among Jews (Cassuto-Salzmann, EI 3 [1954] 187). According to Jossippon, 56-7, the priests made a promise to Alexander the Great to call all their sons born that year (=330 BCE) Alexander. This story is hardly historical, but it may be an attempt to explain the popularity of the nameamong Jews. Alexander was, of course, a popular name for Hellenistic monarchs, see Introduction 1.2.4.2. In S of S Rab 4:13 the name אלכסנדרי is interpreted as a popular transliteration of בנימין, but we have no concrete example to prove it, and see also Klein Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 326-7. See also Introduction 1.2.2.

This name is not mentioned for Greeks, but many names with the element Ταξ(ι) are. For the name Ταξις in Athens see LGPN 2, 423. See also Introduction 1.2. On this name see a long discussion by R. H. Charles, The Assumption of Moses (London 1897) 35-6.
WGE did not know this form as a Greek name, but see LGPN I, 453.
Greek, WGE, 1608 (Φελλεύς), who recorded this as a place name. As a personal name, see LGPNI, 457 (Φελέας).
Greek, WGE, 1621-3. Philip was the name of Alexander the Great’s father, see Introduction 1.2.4.2.
Greek, WGE, 1638. Phoibus is a designation reserved for the Greek god Apollo (Homer, Ilias 1:43). On such names in this corpus see Introduction 1.2.1.
This name is not recorded in Greek, but the forms ̓Ωνάσιμος is mentioned in LGPN I, 488, and ̓Ωνησίμη is mentioned in LGPN II, 481. See also Introduction 1.2.
